No. 79 West Yingze Street Taiyuan 030024 China The direct conversion of syngas to ethanol faces challenges due to catalyst inefficiencies and low ethanol yield. Bulk alloys with an appropriate atomic ratio can exhibit excellent catalytic performance. In this work, a series of Rh x Ni y (111) with different Rh/Ni ratios was rationally designed, and the ethanol preparation from syngas was explored based on density functional theory (DFT) calculation and microkinetic analysis. The results show that Rh1Ni1(111) was screened out to show optimum catalytic performance for ethanol production. This was attributed to a moderate quantity of charge transfer from Ni to Rh atoms, and a medium distance from the d -band center to the Fermi level. Further, to verify the catalytic performance of the catalysts at a Rh: Ni ratio of 1: 1, 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was prepared and its catalytic performance for ethanol preparation from syngas was investigated by comparing it with that of Rh/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/γ-Al2O3. The catalytic performance of 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 has been further confirmed to be preferred over Rh/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/γ-Al2O3, achieving a 23.0 % CO conversion rate with 31.2 % ethanol selectivity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Rh-Ni bulk alloys Ratio Ethanol preparation from syngas Electronic properties Catalytic performance Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ethanol preparation from syngas was considered a feasible and crucial method for transforming raw materials such as coal, natural gas, biomass and carbon dioxide into chemical products with high added value [1–4]. While syngas conversion to ethanol has advanced significantly, controlling CO activation and C − C formation is still a significant difficulty [5]. In light of their higher selectivity to ethanol compared to other metals, Rh-based catalysts have been recognized as the finest among them. However, the widespread application of Rh-based catalysts was constrained by their costly price, the abundance of methane in their products, and low CO conversion rate (2 − 30 %) [6]. To enhance ethanol yields and prevent methane generation, Rh-based catalysts must be modified using promoters. Interaction between two active metals gives bimetallic catalysts distinct chemical characteristics [7]. Significant emphasis has been placed on the design and development of Rh-M bimetallic catalysts in order to improve ethanol production. Rh-Fe(111) inhibited CH4 production [8]; Rh-Mo(111) and Rh-Mn(111) promoted CH3CO formation [9,10] and when Mo remained in the surface layer, the ethanol yield on the Rh-Mo(111) surface could be substantially improved. However, Mo tends to migrate to the subsurface layer [9]. C2 oxygenates were more inclined to form on Rh-Cu(111) surfaces [11,12]. These results demonstrated that ethanol selectivity and generation activity can be improved with appropriate metal doping. Ni-based catalysts have garnered considerable interest owing to their great applicability and a reasonable price for catalyzing syngas reactions [13]. Additionally, the metal Ni can effectively promote CO conversion and carbon chain growth in CO hydrogenation reactions, and displays good hydrogenation ability [14–17]. Bentrup and co-workers [18] noted that Ni additive can tune the strength of CO adsorption and rate of H2 activation over Rh/Al2O3. Li et al. [19] introduced Ni into the K2CO3-modified MoS2 catalyst, which improves ethanol selectivity. Qi et al. [20] studied the catalytic performance of K-MoS2 catalyst with Ni promotion. The Ni addition improved the catalytic activity and the yield of ethanol. The experimental results illustrate that the formation of heterogeneous bimetallic phases between Rh-Ni catalysts can significantly boost methane conversion [21–22]. Theoretically, it is further shown that Rh/Ni(111) displays resilient thermal stability and good catalytic activity for methane dissociation. On the surface of Rh/Ni(111), methane can be transformed to CHO through the CH4* → CH3* → CH2* → CH* → CHO* route [23]. Bimetallic catalysts with the bulk alloy structure was widely adopted for its extraordinary stability and reactivity [24–26]. Studies from Prieto [27] show that Cu-Co alloy phase is active site for the formation of C2+ alcohols, and maintaining that a high proportion of Cu-Co alloy phase is beneficial for the C2+ alcohols. The chemical properties of the catalyst could be modulated by regulating the composition of the bimetallic catalyst, and the appropriate atomic ratio could make bulk alloys show outstanding catalytic performance [7,28]. PtCu3 has been picked for greater performance in terms of C2H4 generation activity, C2H4 selectivity, and self-stability [29]. The optimal electro-catalytic activity of the Pd-Cu/C catalyst on the oxidation of formic acid was observed when the Pd/Cu ratio was 3: 1 [30]. The selectivity to ethylene on Pt/Pd alloy catalysts was most significantly enhanced by Ag at a 1: 1 atomic ratio, whereas Au exhibited the most pronounced impact at a 75 % composition [31]. Pd1Cu3 has demonstrated industrially valuable C2H4 production activity and selectivity to C2H4, along with notable thermal stability [32]. When the molar ratio of Ni: In is 3, the InNi3C0.5 enhances the catalytic activity of the hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate to ethanol by promoting the creation of defect sites, which is favorable for the adsorption of DMO and the formation of intermediate products [33]. However, the effect of Ni introduced into the Rh catalyst needs to be explored on CO conversion and methane formation, as well as the formation of ethanol. Rh-Ni catalysts with high stability have been widely used in CO conversion, CH4 dissociation, and so on. Rh-Ni catalyst outperforms Ni and Rh in indiesel-steam-reforming in terms of hydrogenation activity, stability, sintering and coking resistance [34]. The nanocatalyst Rh49Ni51 has been prepared using the electrochemical co-deposition method, and the stability of which was better than that of pure Ni [35]. For solid Rh-Ni binary alloys, a small amount of Rh was miscible with Ni even at 0 K [36]. In addition, Ni and other metals can form nanocrystals with good stability in the reaction process. Ni x M y (M = Ga, Sn) nanocrystals were crystalline and structurally ordered, and this intermetallic catalyst showed good catalytic stability during long-term acetylene hydrogenation [37]. Structural and compositional stabilities of the ordered Ni-Pt intermetallic nanoparticles lead to enhanced methanol-tolerant ORR activity and durability [38]. Alloy nanoparticles such as Pd-Cu also had excellent catalytic stability [39]. Moreover, Rh-Ni alloys also exhibit outstanding catalytic performance for carbon monoxide oxidation reactions, which were synthesized by exploiting the synergistic effect between Ni and Rh [40]. The introduction of Rh to Ni catalyst could also enhance the ability of the Ni catalyst for H2 activation [41]. The electron transfer from Ni to Rh achieved a synergistic effect between bimetals; thus, Rh/Ni(111) was a good candidate for methane dissociation [23]. However, the influence of the Rh-Ni bulk alloy atomic ratio on selectivity to ethanol and ethanol generation activity was still uncertain. Further, the intrinsic relationship between enhancing selectivity to ethanol and ethanol generation activity, with surface structure and electronic properties of Rh-Ni bulk alloys remained undetermined. The structural and electronic features bimetallic alloy catalysts usually show distinguishes from those of their parent metals, which is conducive to obtaining innovative catalysts with better stability, activity and product selectivity [42]. Pd3Cu catalysts have enhanced selectivity and catalytic activity with regard to CO2 formation during HCOOH oxidation, which was attributed to the bimetallic synergetic effect enabled by the Cu atom electron donation to the Pd trimer [43]. The catalytic activity of Co was enhanced through the interaction of Cu and Co atoms on a Cu-Co bimetallic with a Cu-rich surface. This enhancement was particularly advantageous for the carbon chain expansion that occurred during ethanol formation [44]. Pd3P(010) demonstrated moderate amounts of charge transfer between its M and P atoms, and its d-band center was located far from the Fermi level. Consequently, it exhibited high selectivity to C2H4 [45]. It can be seen that the bimetallic alloy catalysts exhibit excellent performance due to their distinctive structural and electronic properties. Furthermore, how the electronic structure of the Rh-Ni bimetallic alloy catalyst influences the preparation of ethanol from syngas needs to be investigated further. In this work, the reaction mechanism of ethanol preparation from syngas over Rh x Ni y (111) (x: y = 3: 1, 1: 1, 1: 3), which will be investigated based on density functional theory (DFT) calculations and micro-kinetic modeling. The Rh x Ni y (111) will be further compared with pure Rh and pure Ni to facilitate the assessment of the catalytic performance. Meanwhile, the optimum ratio of Rh-Ni catalyst will be screened. In addition, by examining electronic properties of Rh x Ni y (111), the mechanism by which atomic ratio modulates the catalytic performance will be elucidated, as well as the roles of Rh and Ni. Furthermore, the catalytic performance of the screened Rh-Ni catalysts will be experimentally verified by comparative analysis with pure Rh and pure Ni. The impact of Ni introduction over Rh-based catalysts on ethanol generation from syngas will be elucidated and the optimal Rh-Ni ratio will be screened using an integration of theory and experiment. The work results are expected to provide clues for the design of high-performance Rh-based catalysts. 2 Methodology 2.1 Computational methods All of the density functional theory calculations in this work were executed using the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) software [46]. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange-correlation functional was implemented [47]. The plane-wave cut off energy of 400 eV was selected for the purpose of describing the electrical wave functions. For each model, a 3 × 3 × 1 Brillouin zone Monkhorst-Pack k-point grid was employed [48]. For the structure optimization to reach convergence, the force that each atom acts and the energy variation between two consecutive stages had to be below 1 × 10−5 eV and 0.03 eV·Å −1, respectively. Given that Rh and Ni are magnetic atoms, the consideration of spin polarization was incorporated into each calculation. The initial step in the investigation of the reaction transition state was the utilization of the Climbing Image Nudged Elastic Band (CI-NEB) technique to identify the path of least energy between the reactants and products. Subsequently, the obtained transition state was subjected to optimization using the Dimer method, and the convergence criterion was reached when the force constant was less than or equal to 0.05 eV·Å −1 [49,50]. The confirmation of the transition state structure was achieved using vibrational frequency calculation, wherein a single imaginary frequency was produced at the saddle points. Ethanol preparation from syngas often occurred experimentally in the temperature range 500−625 K [51,52]. Activation free energy (G a) and reaction free energy (∆G) were assessed at 525 K in this work (details of relevant energy calculations are listed in the Supplementary Material). 2.2 Computational models The activity and selectivity for ethanol generation are affected by the structure of the Rh crystal facet. The FCC Rh has demonstrated greater ethanol generating activity versus the HCP Rh, owing to the exposure of much denser active facets. The Rh(111) crystal plane accounts for 66.95 % of the FCC crystal phase, and it has demonstrated higher ethanol selectivity with respect to other crystal planes [53,54]. As it turns out, the (111) crystal facet of Rh-Ni catalyst is employed in this work. The lattice constants of the optimized Rh-Ni cell are: a = b = c = 3.79 Å for Rh3Ni1 (111), a = 3.57 Å and b = c = 3.76 Å for Rh1Ni1(111), a = b = 3.62 Å and c = 3.63 Å for Rh1Ni3(111), which were in accordance with the lattice constants of FCC crystalline phase Rh (a = b = c = 3.88 Å) measured by previous experiments [54]. Rh x Ni y (111) surface was modeled by the four layer p(3 × 3) slab model. To replicate the bulk environment of a catalyst under realistic circumstances, a vacuum layer with a thickness of 15 Å was selected to separate the slab contacts. During the calculations, the fixed location of the two lowest layers was maintained, while the rest of the layers and adsorbed species were permitted to relax. The stability of the constructed catalyst model was explored by calculating the mixing energy, as stated in Table 1 [55]. Evidently, it is apparent that the mixing energy of all catalysts exhibited a negative value, suggesting the stable existence and potential applicability of the model constructed in this work for the ethanol synthesis from syngas. With respect to the facts shown in Fig. 1 , it can be observed that the Rh3Ni1(111) surface displayed a total count of eight adsorption sites. These sites were identified as: top-Rh, top-Ni, Rh-Ni bridge, Rh-Rh bridge, hcp1, hcp2, fcc1 and fcc2 sites. Specifically, the Rh1Ni1(111) surface exhibits nine adsorption sites, namely the top-Rh, top-Ni, Rh-Ni bridge, Rh-Rh bridge, Ni-Ni bridge, hcp1, hcp2, fcc1 and fcc2 sites. Similarly, the Rh1Ni3(111) surface shows eight adsorption sites, including top-Rh, top-Ni, Rh-Ni bridge, Rh-Rh bridge, hcp1, hcp2, fcc1 and fcc2 sites. 2.3 Catalyst preparation and structure identification Using 10 % Rh (NO3)3 hydrate as the precursor, which was purchased from Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd., China, the supported Rh-based catalyst was synthesized on the γ-Al2O3 (which was purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation Co., Ltd., China.) support by following an incipient wetness impregnation method [56]. Usually, 8.0 mL of ethanol was used to dissolve the aqueous solutions of Ni(NO3)2•6H2O and Rh(NO3)3 (which were bought from Aladdin Industrial Corporation Co., Ltd., China). Then the mixed solution was added by drop to the 5.0 g γ-Al2O3 under vigorous magnetic stirring at room temperature. The suspension was stirred for 0.5 h at the same temperature to form paste. A 24 h air aging period was followed by drying in a vacuum oven at 393 K for 12 h, followed by 4 h of calcination in a muffle furnace at 623 K. The synthesized catalysts are denoted as 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3, in which the molar ratio of Rh and Ni was 1: 1. The last step in preparing the catalysts for usage was to sift them to a 40–60 mesh size. The 1Rh/γ-Al2O3 and 1Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts replicated the 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 approach in their preparation, which is evidenced by X-ray diffractograms (XRD) in Fig. S1. The synthesized catalysts are denoted as 1Rh/γ-Al2O3 and 1Ni/γ-Al2O3. And the detailed process for evaluating catalysts could be extracted from the Supplementary Material. 2.4 Catalyst characterization The specific surface area (BET), pore diameter and pore volume of the samples were obtained by N2 physisorption measurement at 77 K on a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 apparatus. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out using a TP-5080 multipurpose automatic adsorption instrument. The as-prepared sample (0.1 g) was first pretreated at 60 °C in N2 for 30 min prior to a TPR measurement. During the TPR experiment, H2/N2 (molar ratio of H2/N2= 1/9) was used at 50 mL min−1 and the temperature was ramped from 60 °C to 900 °C at 10 °C min−1. The effluent gas was analyzed with a TCD. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha instrument equipped with a hemispherical analyzer operated in a constant pass energy mode, and an Al Kα X-ray source operated at 6 mA and 12 kV. Prior to the test, the sample was reduced in situ at 300 °C for 2 h in the pretreatment chamber. The binding energy values were calibrated with the C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV. The high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) with an energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) was measured on a transmission electron microscope JEM-2100F. The high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) imaging and energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectrometry was measured on a JEM ARM300F instrument. Prior to the test, the sample was pretreated in diluted hydrogen (10 % H2 in N2, 50 mL min−1) at 300 °C for 2 h. 2.5 Catalyst evaluation Syngas conversion over the 1Rh/γ-Al2O3, 1Rh1Ni / γ-Al2O3 and 1Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts is investigated under the conditions of 513 K, 1.0 MPa, space velocity of 2400 mL h−1 g−1 and H2: CO =2: 1. The syngas was into a reactor with inert quartz sand for blank studies, and no products were observed under the same reaction conditions over γ-Al2O3. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Reaction pathways for ethanol formation It is a broad agreement that the generation of ethanol from syngas consists two steps [57], as illustrated in Fig. 2 : (1) in order to generate the critical intermediate CH x , two reaction pathways are available, the first involves the direct dissociation of CO to generate C, followed by a gradual hydrogenation of C to yield CH x (x = 1, 2, 3) intermediates [58]; the second pathway employs the CO hydrogen-assisted dissociation mechanism, whereby CO is hydrogenated initially to yield CH x O(x = 1, 2, 3) or CH x OH(x = 1, 2), and subsequently the C − O bond in CH x O(x = 1, 2, 3) or CH x OH(x = 1, 2) is broken to generate CH x (x = 1, 2, 3) intermediates and O or OH species. Meanwhile, by-product CH3OH may be produced through CH3O and CH2OH hydrogenation, which will notably decrease CH x selectivity. It deserves to be mentioned that OH on the catalyst surface could participate in CO activation as a co-adsorption promoter. (2) CO/CHO interacts with CH x to produce C2 oxygenate precursors CH x CO/CH x CHO, which is subsequently hydrogenated to produce ethoxide groups. The ultimate product ethanol can be generated by further hydrogenation following the formation of ethoxide [9]. At the same time, CH4 can be produced by CH x hydrogenation, and C2 hydrocarbons can be produced through CH x coupling [59–62]. It is speculated that Rh-Ni bulk alloys will tackle the concern of low CO conversion and then raise concentration of CH x intermediates, hence enhancing ethanol yield. 3.2 CHx formation from syngas (x = 1, 2, 3) 3.2.1 H2 adsorption and dissociation For the purpose of supplying a hydrogen source for syngas conversion, H2 adsorption and dissociation on the Rh x Ni y (111) (x: y = 3: 1, 1: 1, 1: 3) surface are first taken into consideration. There are two distinct forms of hydrogen adsorption: parallel adsorption and vertical adsorption. After the hydrogen molecules adsorbed vertically are optimized, they escape to the surface. The hydrogen molecules in parallel form are self-dissociated on the surface (see Fig. S2 in Supplementary Material). As a consequence, hydrogen dissociation occurs readily on the Rh x Ni y (111), which can provide an adequate quantity of hydrogen for syngas conversion. 3.2.2 Activation of initial CO The activation of CO is a crucial initial step in the process of ethanol production, and there are two major mechanisms of activation, including hydrogenation to generate CHO or COH, as well as direct dissociation to form C and O [63]. The activation free energy and reaction free energy, as well as the imaginary frequency for each elementary step of CO activation can be seen in Tables S1 and S2. The energy barriers to be overcome for CO direct dissociation on the surfaces of Rh3Ni1(111), Rh3Ni1(111) and Rh1Ni3(111) are relatively high, with 355.7, 300.7 and 300.8 kJ·mol−1, respectively. This implies that the formation of C is relatively difficult on the surfaces of Rh x Ni y (111). As a result, the formation of CH x intermediates via the hydrogenation of C is extremely impossible. CO hydrogenation to CHO prefers to occur over the Rh3Ni1(111), Rh3Ni1(111) and Rh1Ni3(111) as depicted in Fig. 3 , with activation free energies of 105.9, 91.2 and 132.7 kJ·mol−1, respectively. In parallel, earlier studies have demonstrated that CO tends to hydrogenate to generate CHO on both Rh(111) and Ni(111). The energy barriers that need to be overcome are 139.9 and 152.7 kJ·mol−1, respectively [54,64]. In addition, the effect of OH on CO activation has also been investigated. When surface OH species are utilized as a co-adsorption promoter, the activation of CO is more likely to hydrogenate to form CHO on the surfaces of Rh3Ni1(111), Rh1Ni1(111) and Rh1Ni3(111) as without OH. The corresponding activation free energies for this process are 130.8, 131.5 and 132.3 kJ·mol− 1, respectively. Therefore, H-assisted activation of CO without OH remains dominant compared to that with OH over the Rh x Ni y (111). In agreement with the results on the Co(0001) surface [65], CO is more readily converted to CHO key intermediates by H-assisted activation on the Rh x Ni y (111) surface. While on the surface of Co(111), the presence of OH can accelerate the H-assisted CO activation [65]. Also, Zha et al. [66] demonstrated that OH stimulates CO hydrogenation activation to produce CH x species on the Co-doped Cu(111) surface. In addition, in the hydrogen-rich atmosphere of syngas, OH species readily hydrogenate to form H2O over the surfaces of Rh3Ni1(111), Rh3Ni1(111) and Rh1Ni3(111), which overcome energy barriers of 63.5, 72.7 and 49.6 kJ·mol−1, respectively. And H2O is easily desorbed from the catalyst surface (desorption energies are 9.3, 0.9 and 12.6 kJ·mol−1, respectively). It can be seen that OH prefers to form H2O via combining with H, rather than generate CHO intermediate via reacting with CO on Rh x Ni y (111). It shows that OH does not affect the subsequent ethanol production to a certain extent. The Rh x Ni y (111) catalyst does not alter the primary pathway of CO activation, and are kinetically more advantageous for CHO production, especially the Rh3Ni1(111) and Rh1Ni1(111). Therefore, CHO is produced primarily through hydrogen-assisted dissociation of CO on the surfaces of Rh(111), Ni(111) and Rh x Ni y (111). The activation free energies required for CHO generation are ordered as follows: Ni(111) (152.7 kJ·mol−1) [64] > Rh(111) (139.9 kJ·mol−1) [54] > Rh1Ni3(111) (132.7 kJ·mol−1) > Rh3Ni1(111) (105.9 kJ·mol−1) > Rh1Ni1(111) (91.2 kJ·mol−1). In general, the addition of Ni improves the performance of Rh-based catalysts to activate CO, which makes preparation for the subsequent reactions to provide CH x in large quantities. 3.2.3 CHx (x = 1, 2, 3) generated via syngas Launching with CHO, the formation of CH x (x = 1, 2, 3) can be achieved primarily through hydrogen-assisted dissociation of CH x O (x = 1, 2, 3) as well as dissociation of CH x OH (x = 1, 2). For the formation of CH, among the three possible paths for CH formation [67], the favorable paths on the surface of Rh3Ni1(111) are CHO+H → CH+OH and CHO+H → CHOH → CH+OH. The overall barriers that must be crossed for the above pathways are 174.1 and 177.3 kJ·mol−1, respectively. These exist two parallel paths for the formation of CH. CH is more readily generated kinetically over the surface of Rh1Ni1(111) via the following pathway: CHO+H → CHOH → CH+OH, which requires overcoming the overall barrier of 145.1 kJ·mol−1. The preferred pathway for CH formation on the surface of Rh1Ni3(111) is CHO+H → CH+OH, the overall barrier to be overcome is 197.2 kJ·mol−1 (see Fig. S3). On the surface of Rh(111), CH is primarily produced by means of CHOH dissociation, with an overall barrier of 225.9 kJ·mol−1. In light of the discussion above, Rh1Ni1(111) exhibits with the highest activity for CH generation, whereas Rh1Ni3(111) offers with the lowest activity among three Rh x Ni y (111). However, they are higher than Rh(111) and Ni(111) with activation free energies of 225.9 and 235.5 kJ·mol−1 [54,64]. It is reasonable to arrive at the conclusion that Rh-Ni bulk alloys can accelerate the formation of CH comparing with Rh(111) and Ni(111). Among the five potential pathways for CH2 production [67], the most advantageous path for CH2 on Rh3Ni1(111), Rh1Ni1(111) and Rh1Ni3(111) is: CHO+H → CHOH → CH+H → CH2, the overall barriers required for the pathway are 177.3, 145.1 and 243.3 kJ·mol−1, respectively (see Fig. S4). The overall barriers to be overcome for CH2 formation are ordered as follows: Rh(111) (283.5 kJ·mol−1) [54] > Rh1Ni3(111) (243.3 kJ·mol−1) > Ni(111) (235.5 kJ·mol−1) [64] > Rh3Ni1(111) (177.3 kJ·mol−1) > Rh1Ni1(111) (145.1 kJ·mol−1), in which the surface of Rh1Ni1(111) exhibits best catalytic activity, and Rh-Ni bulk alloys show higher catalytic activity than the Rh(111). Out of the six potential ways considered, the subsequent approach is deemed to be the most optimal for CH3 production on the surfaces of Rh3Ni1(111) and Rh1Ni1(111): CHO+H → CHOH → CH+H → CH2+H→ CH3. The related overall barriers to be surmounted are 177.3 and 165.6 kJ·mol−1, respectively. Since CH2O is weakly physical adsorption on the Rh1Ni3(111) surface at 525 K, it is easy to desorb from the surface (desorption energy is 20.6 kJ·mol−1). As a result, the formation of CH3 via CH2O intermediate is extremely impossible. The Rh1Ni3(111) surface exhibits a highly favorable pathway for the formation of CH3, which proceeds as follows: CHO+H → CHOH → CH+H → CH2+H → CH3, with an overall barrier to overcome of 243.3 kJ·mol−1 (see Fig. S5). The overall barriers to be overcome for CH3 generation on pure Rh and pure Ni surfaces are 322.1 and 235.5 kJ·mol−1, respectively [54,64]. CH3 is more easily generated on 1: 1 and 3: 1 surfaces. The Rh-Ni bulk alloys can significantly enhance CH3 generation activity compared to Rh(111), with Rh1Ni1(111) being the most advantageous. The overall barriers to overcome on the Rh3Ni1(111) surface for CH, CH2 and CH3 are similar as stated in Fig. 4 are 174.1, 177.3 and 177.3 kJ·mol−1, respectively. Furthermore, the favorable path for CH2 and CH3 formation is further hydrogenation of the resulting CH. CH2 and CH3 are highly unstable on Rh3Ni1(111) and prone to dehydrogenation dissociation to form CH and CH2, respectively. Which only requires activation free energies of 2.6 and 18.4 kJ·mol−1, respectively. Consequently, CH on Rh3Ni1(111) surface is more dominant. On the surface of Rh1Ni1(111), the generation of both CH and CH2 is advantageous. However, the CH2 monomer only requires activation free energies of 2.2 kJ·mol−1 to dissociate into CH after formation. Consequently, the predominant CH x monomer on the surface of Rh1Ni1(111) is CH. The formation of CH on Rh1Ni3(111) surface is kinetically favorable relative to the two CH x . Therefore, CH on the surface of Rh1Ni3(111) is the predominant CH x monomer. In accordance with Rh(111) and Ni(111), the intermediate that is most predominant among CH x (x = 1, 2, 3) is CH on Rh x Ni y (111). Additionally, based on the analysis presented previously, Rh-Ni bulk alloys are more capable of contributing a substantial quantity of CH species to the subsequent ethanol generation. 3.2.4 Methanol produced by syngas Given the weak physical adsorption of CH2O on the surfaces of Rh x Ni y (111) (x: y = 3: 1, 1: 1, 1: 3) at 525 K, it is readily desorbed (desorption energies are 18.2, 20.2 and 20.6 kJ·mol−1, respectively). As a result, CH3OH formation via the hydrogenation of CH2O is impossible due to the easy desorption of CH2O. CH3OH is generated by the following pathways: CHO+H → CHOH+H → CH2OH+H → CH3OH. As depicted in Fig. 4, the overall barriers required for CH3OH formation on Rh x Ni y (111) are 211.8, 190.3 and 270.3 kJ·mol−1, respectively (see Fig. S6). The gap about the activation free energy required for the formation of CH and CH3OH is, in turn as follows: Rh1Ni3(111) (73.1 kJ·mol−1) > Rh1Ni1(111) (45.2 kJ·mol−1) > Rh3Ni1(111) (37.7 kJ·mol−1) > Rh(111) (36.9 kJ·mol−1) [54] > Ni(111) (8.5 kJ·mol−1) [64]. This means that the generation of CH from syngas is preferable to CH3OH, which exhibits a negligible effect on CH generation. The catalytic activity of Rh x Ni y (111) surface to CH x (x = 1, 2, 3) is improved, and the selectivity to CH x is increased, in particular CH. 3.3 Formation of ethanol 3.3.1 The CC chain generation According to the above description, after determining the optimal CH x monomer to be CH, the CC chain can be generated by the insertion reaction between CH and CO/CHO. Therefore, while deciding which of CHCO/CHCHO is C2 oxygenates precursor, both the formation of CHO and the insertion reaction between CO/CHO and CH are taken into account (see Fig. S7). The rate constants of the crucial steps are calculated at 500, 525, 550, 575, 600 and 625 K. The activation free energy and reaction free energy, as well as the imaginary frequency for each elementary step can be seen in Tables S3 and S4. The rate constants of CHO synthesis and its insertion into CH on the Rh3Ni1(111) and Rh1Ni1(111) surfaces are significantly higher than those of CO insertion into CH at the same temperature as illustrated in Fig. 5 . Thereby, the creation of CC chains on the aforementioned two surfaces is primarily determined by the insertion reaction between CHO and CH. On the other hand, CH interacts faster with CHO than CO on the surface of Rh1Ni3(111), but CHO formation is not dominant. Thus, specific C2 oxygenate precursors cannot be identified, and both CC chain formation mechanisms are investigated. 3.3.2 Ethanol generation On the basis of the foregoing assessment, further calculations are performed on the hydrogenation of C2 oxygenate precursors to generate ethanol (see Fig. S8). Both Rh3Ni1(111) and Rh1Ni1(111) exhibit the following advantageous pathway for ethanol formation as shown in Fig. 6 : CH+CHO+H → CHCHO+H → CH2CHO+H → CH3CHO+H → CH3CH2O+H → C2H5OH. The activation free energies needed for this pathway are 150.3 and 140.5 kJ·mol−1, and endothermic with energies of 93.0 and 85.3 kJ·mol−1, respectively. The predominant pathway for ethanol synthesis on the Rh1Ni3(111) surface is CH+CO+H → CHCO+H → CH2CO+H → CH3CO+H → CH3CHO+H → CH3CHOH+H → C2H5OH. The overall barrier to overcome for this path is 234.6 kJ·mol−1, and it is endothermic with an energy of 187.0 kJ·mol−1. When the Rh/Ni ratio is 1: 1, the Rh-Ni bulk alloys present the highest catalytic activity for ethanol generation. Rh3Ni1(111) and Rh1Ni1(111) surfaces display comparable C − C chain formation ability with Rh(111) surfaces, and the required activation free energies for C − C chain formation are 72.8, 71.5 and 71.1 kJ·mol−1, respectively (see Table S3) [54]. The comparatively poor C − C chain formation ability is exhibited on the surface of Rh1Ni3(111), requiring an activation free energy of 104.2 kJ·mol−1. Subsequently, the ability of C2 oxygenate precursors by hydrogenation to yield ethanol is evaluated, with the surface of Rh-Ni bulk alloys being weaker than Rh(111) (71.7 kJ·mol−1), due to the higher endothermic of this approach. 4 Micro-kinetic analysis Micro-kinetic modeling is employed to simulate the realistic experimental conditions ( p C O = 4 atm, p H 2 = 8 atm, T = 525 K), which aim to examine the effect of experimental temperature, pressure, and species coverage on the catalytic performance of ethanol preparation from syngas over the Rh x Ni y (111) further, calculation details can be seen in Tables S5 to S10. By comparing the formation rates of methanol, methane, acetylene and ethanol as stated in Fig. 7 , it can be found that on the surface of Rh3Ni1(111), the formation rates are as follows: lg r C H 3 O H > lg r C H 4 = lg r C 2 H 5 O H > lg r C 2 H 2 . Methanol is the main product. Ethanol and methane exhibit equal generation rate, and both of which are lower than methanol. The order of generation rates on the surface of Rh1Ni1(111) is: lg r C 2 H 5 O H > lg r C H 4 > lg r C H 3 O H > lg r C 2 H 2 , and the formation rate of ethanol is significantly higher than that of methane and methanol. Hence, ethanol is the predominant product on the surface of Rh1Ni1(111). The formation rate is as follows on the surface of Rh1Ni3(111): lg r C 2 H 5 O H > lg r C H 3 O H > lg r C H 4 > lg r C 2 H 2 , ethanol and methanol are formed at much higher rates than methane. The main product is ethanol, and methanol is the main by-product. The acetylene generation rate is negligible when compared to methanol, methane and ethanol on the surface of Rh x Ni y (111). The generation rate of ethanol on Rh1Ni1(111) is approximately 8 times that on Rh1Ni3(111). Methane production can be significantly inhibited on the surfaces of Rh1Ni1(111) and Rh1Ni3(111). It can be concluded that when the Rh: Ni ratio is 1: 1, the catalyst exhibits the peak catalytic performance for ethanol generation from syngas compared to the rest of the ratios. Rh x Ni y (111) surface shows a substantial suppression of methane formation in contrast to the Rh(111) and Ni(111), where methane are the predominant product [6,64]. Ni modified Rh catalyst is more effective in improving CO conversion and inhibiting methane formation compared to pure Rh. While promoters for the top 10 Rh-based catalysts reported in the past decade were Mn or the binary or tertiary combinations of Fe, Li and Mn, according to their C2+oxygenate yield [68–72], the present result demonstrates that Rh-Ni catalysts can also exhibit excellent catalytic performance for ethanol generation from syngas. 5 Microscopic property analysis 5.1 CO activation affected by electronic properties with different ratios The critical first step for ethanol preparation from syngas on the Rh x Ni y (111) (x: y = 3: 1, 1: 1, 1: 3) are the CO+H → CHO reaction. According to the DFT calculations, both Rh3Ni1(111) and Rh1Ni1(111) presents good catalytic activity for the CO activation. Therefore, the CO+H → CHO reaction is analyzed. The degree of C − O bond activation on metal catalysts is predominantly determined by the interplay between d orbitals of metal catalysts and the 2π* anti-bonding orbital of CO molecules. The activation of molecules becomes increasingly facilitated as the number of electrons in the anti-bonding orbitals increases [73,74]. More electron transfer is necessary to activate the C − O bonds of CO molecules adsorbed on Rh x Ni y (111). As presented in Fig. 8 , the projection state density and differential charge density plots of CO reveal that the 2π* orbital of CO in the adsorbed state embraces d orbital electrons, which are from the surface metal of the Rh x Ni y (111) (x: y = 3: 1, 1: 1, 1: 3). Therefore, the number of electrons in the 2π* orbital of CO is 3.095, 2.967 and 2.834 e, respectively. The number of electrons occupied in the CO anti-bonding orbitals reduces as the Rh/Ni ratios drop, as does the amount of electrons lost by C atoms (0.651, 0.595 and 0.585 e), revealing that the interaction between CO molecules and metal catalysts steadily weakens. As it stands, Rh3Ni1(111) and Rh1Ni1(111) catalysts show superior catalytic activity for CO activation relative to Rh(111) and Ni(111). The gap between the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) and the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) could be used as a signal for degree of difficulty associated with species activation [75,76]. A smaller gap value (Gap H−L) between E LUMO and E HOMO implies a higher reactivity [77–79]. Pure Rh catalysts have an energy gap value of 0.143 eV, while the catalyst energy gap value decreases to 0.080 and 0.086 eV when the Rh/Ni ratio is 3: 1 or 1: 1 as presented in Fig. 9 , respectively. The reaction molecules are easily activated by the catalyst when the Rh/Ni ratio is 3: 1 or 1: 1. When CO is adsorbed on Rh(111) and Rh x Ni y (111), the HOMO orbitals of the metal provide electrons to the LUMO orbitals of the adsorbed CO. The HOMO-LUMO energy gaps of CO adsorbed on Rh and Rh x Ni y (111) are 3.81, 2.58, 2.38 and 3.20 eV, respectively. Compared with Rh catalysts, Rh x Ni y (111) reduced the energy gap and improved CO activation capacity. 5.2 Analysis of electronic properties on catalytic performance of Rh-Ni catalysts The electrical properties of the catalysts are further examined to delve into what causes the distinction in catalytic performance for the ethanol synthesis from syngas on Rh x Ni y (111). Rh atoms receive electrons as depicted in Table 2 , and the obtained charge amounts are 0.180, 0.239 and 0.096 e, respectively. While Ni atoms lose electrons, the lost charge amounts are 0.120, 0.045 and 0.145 e, respectively. As a consequence, Rh is the electron acceptor, whereas Ni is the electron donor on Rh x Ni y (111). The greater amount electrons that are moved from Ni to Rh on the catalyst as the Rh/Ni ratio decreases, the greater the number of electrons captured by Rh atoms. The Rh atoms on Rh x Ni y (111) are further away from the Fermi level in comparison to the Ni atoms as shown in Fig. 10 , which indicates that the Rh atoms exhibit enhanced catalytic activity following the interaction between Rh and Ni. It can also be deduced that the Rh-Ni surface increases Rh catalytic activity, which makes CH x production easier. With the decrease in Rh/Ni ratios, the coordination number of Ni atoms around Rh increases (1, 1.33 and 2, respectively), the d-band center of Rh x Ni y (111) is closer to the Fermi level than Rh(111) (with values of −1.74, −1.70, −1.59 and −1.88 eV, respectively) (see Fig. S9). The greater catalytic activity of Rh-Ni bulk alloys makes the conversion of CO and the generation of CH x more advantageous. As a consequence, surface Rh atoms serve as catalytic active sites in ethanol preparation from syngas, and Ni atoms perform as electronic donors to achieve bimetallic synergetic effect. 5.3 The influences of catalyst electronic properties on catalytic performance, based on micro-kinetic modeling Combined with the above analysis of electronic properties and micro-kinetic modeling, it can be seen that ethanol generation activity has a volcanic-type curve relationship with the d-band center as illustrated in Fig. 11 , and charge transfer between Rh and Ni exhibits the same relationship with ethanol selectivity and generative activity [80]. Compared with Rh3Ni1(111) and Rh1Ni3(111) catalysts, the ethanol generation activity on the surface of Rh1Ni1(111) is improved. This is attributed to the modest quantity of charge transfer from Ni to Rh atoms, and the medium distance from the d-band center to the Fermi level [81,82]. 6 Performance evaluation of Rh-Ni catalyst 6.1 Physicochemical property The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area, pore volume and pore diameter of 1Rh/γ-Al2O3, 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 and 1Ni/γ-Al2O3 are displayed in Table S11. The surface areas of the three catalysts mentioned above are similar, ranging from 108.6 to 114.9 m2g−1. The correlation between the surface area of each catalyst and its catalytic performance raises the possibility that surface area of catalyst may have an impact on ethanol yield. 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 has the largest pore volume with a value of 0.399 cm3g−1, followed by 1Rh/γ-Al2O3 with a value of 0.398 cm3g−1, and 1Ni/γ-Al2O3 presents the smallest pore volume with a value of 0.387 cm3g−1. Furthermore, 1Rh/γ-Al2O3 and 1Ni/γ-Al2O3 have similar pore diameters of 13.5 nm. In comparison, 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 possesses a smaller pore size of 12.9 nm. It indicates that the pore volume and diameter of Rh-Ni/γ-Al2O3 have little effect on catalytic performance. Metal loadings determined by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP) demonstrates that the molar ratio of Rh: Ni is 1: 1, the Rh weight content is 1.0 % and the Ni weight content is 0.63 % on 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 (see Table S11) [83–85]. Temperature-programmed reduction in H2 (H2-TPR) technique can be used to assess the reducibility of the catalyst, which is a crucial factor influencing its catalytic performance [86,87]. H2-TPR is employed to explore reduction behavior of the 1Rh/γ-Al2O3, 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 and 1Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, as shown in Figure S10. In the temperature range of 80–250 °C, 1Rh/γ-Al2O3 and 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 show two reduction peaks, which could be attributed to the two-step reduction of Rh3+ to Rh+ (80–170 °C) and Rh+ to Rh0 (180–320 °C), respectively [88]. While the intensity of the reduction peak at 80–170 °C on the 1Rh/γ-Al2O3 is small, suggesting that a few Rh+ are remained on the 1Rh/γ-Al2O3. In the temperature range of 150–250 °C, the peaks occur at 226 °C for 1Rh/γ-Al2O3 and 248 °C for 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3. It indicates that the Rh species on the 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 are easier to be reduced forming Rh0 than that on the 1Rh/γ-Al2O3. In addition, the H2 uptake of 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 in the temperature range of 180–320 °C is higher than that of 1Rh/γ-Al2O3, indicating that more Rh0 is formed on the 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 with respect to 1Rh/γ-Al2O3. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) studies are utilized to gain a deeper insight into surface compositions and the chemical states of 1Rh/γ-Al2O3, 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 and 1Ni/γ-Al2O3 [89]. XPS results for 1Rh/γ-Al2O3 and 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 are presented in Fig. 12 and Fig. S11. Rh3+ is responsible for the Rh 3d5/2 binding energies (BE) on the 1Rh/γ-Al2O3 and 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, which are displayed in Fig. S11 at 309.6 and 309.8 eV, respectively [90]. After the catalysts are reduced in H2, the Rh 3d5/2 BE at 308.9 and 309.1 eV are observed on 1Rh/γ-Al2O3 and 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3, respectively. These observations are attributed to Rh+ species. Additional minor peaks at 308.3 and 308.1 eV, associated with Rh0 species, are also visible on the two samples. On the other hand, the dominant peak on 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 is the Rh+specie peak at 309.1 eV and the Rh0 specie peak at 308.1 eV. This supports the finding that in the H2-TPR, more Rh0 is produced on the 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 than on 1Rh/γ-Al2O3. More Rh0 sites on 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 enhance the CO hydrogen-assisted dissociation to produce CH x intermediates. Furthermore, Ni2+ is responsible for the Ni 2p3/2 peaks at 856.7–857.4 eV (see Fig. S11) [91]. The results demonstrated the coexistence of Rh0, Rh+ and Ni2+ species on the surfaces of 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 [92,93]. High-angle annular dark-field imaging scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) has been used to examine the nanostructure and elemental distribution of 1Rh/γ-Al2O3 (see Fig. S12a), 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 (see Fig. S13a) and 1Ni/γ-Al2O3 (see Fig. S14a). X-ray energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) results are shown in Fig. S12 to Fig. S14. On the aforementioned three catalysts, the metal nanoparticle is found to be highly dispersed and relatively uniform, with mean diameters of 1.1 to 1.3 nm [94,95]. 6.2 Catalytic performance To further validate the catalytic performance of 1Rh1Ni catalysts, 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 is prepared, and its catalytic performance is compared with those of 1Rh/γ-Al2O3 and 1Ni/γ-Al2O3. Metal particles supported by γ-Al2O3 have been found to be effective for the catalytic conversion of CO [96–99] and the metal particles are well dispersed over γ-Al2O3 due to their high porosity and specific surface area [100–104]. The methanol content decreases to 6.7 % and the ethanol selectivity on 1Ni/γ-Al2O3 is 0 % when the CO conversion rate is 1.8 %. At the moment, the main products of the 1Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalytic synthesis gas conversion are methane and C2+ hydrocarbons, with a selectivity of 64.3 % and 21.2 %, respectively (see Fig. 13 and Table S12). However, the ethanol yield on 1Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst is only 2.8 %. With a CO conversion of 23.0 % on the 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, at which time the ethanol selectivity and yield reached 31.2 % and 7.2 %, respectively. While the selectivity of methane and C2+ hydrocarbons dropped to 9.1 % and 2.4 %, correspondingly. The CO conversion on 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 is about 2.0 and 12.8 times higher than that on 1Rh/γ-Al2O3 and 1Ni/γ-Al2O3, respectively. Compared to 1Rh/γ-Al2O3, the ethanol yield on 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 is 2.6 times higher. As a consequence, 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 exhibits significantly better catalytic performance than pure metals Rh and Ni loaded on γ-Al2O3. The primary factor contributing to this improvement in catalytic performance is the addition of Ni to Rh-based catalysts. It can be concluded that the 1Rh1Ni catalyst can significantly improve CO conversion and ethanol production, which is consistent with the results predicted by calculations. 7 Conclusion In this work, the mechanism and catalytic performance of ethanol generation from syngas were systematically investigated over Rh x Ni y (111) using DFT calculations and micro-kinetic modeling. The preferred Rh: Ni ratio was screened and the role of Ni was revealed by comparing the results with those of Rh(111) and Ni(111). Firstly, Rh1Ni1(111) catalyst is screened out as having better activity for ethanol generation. Ethanol is the main product on both Rh1Ni1(111) and Rh1Ni3(111) catalysts, and ethanol generation rate on Rh1Ni1(111) is eight times higher than that on Rh1Ni3(111). The improvement in ethanol production activity is attributed to a modest quantity of charge transfer from Ni to Rh atoms, and the medium distance from the d-band center to the Fermi level on Rh1Ni1(111). Furthermore, 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was prepared and its catalytic performance was investigated by comparing it with that of 1Rh/γ-Al2O3 and 1Ni/γ-Al2O3. Consistent with the DFT results when Rh: Ni was 1: 1, the CO conversion was improved, which in turn increased the ethanol yield. The CO conversion rate of 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst can reach 23.0 %, which is about 2 times higher than 1Rh/γ-Al2O3, and 12.8 times higher than 1Ni/γ-Al2O3. On the 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, at which time the ethanol selectivity and yield reached 31.2 % and 7.2 %, respectively. The ethanol yield is 2.6 times higher than that on 1Rh/γ-Al2O3. Based on theoretical and experimental calculations, it was determined that the 1Rh1Ni catalyst had outstanding catalytic performance in ethanol production from syngas. The addition of Ni to Rh-based catalyst has been shown to increase CO conversion and thus increase the ethanol production both experiments and theoretical calculations. When the Rh: Ni ratio is 1: 1, the Rh-Ni catalyst demonstrates exceptional catalytic performance for ethanol production from syngas. This finding gives a guide on the structural information for reasonably designing the Rh-Ni catalysts with high performance in ethanol production from syngas. coredata.dc:description: The direct conversion of syngas to ethanol faces challenges due to catalyst inefficiencies and low ethanol yield. Bulk alloys with an appropriate atomic ratio can exhibit excellent catalytic performance. In this work, a series of Rh x Ni y (111) with different Rh/Ni ratios was rationally designed, and the ethanol preparation from syngas was explored based on density functional theory (DFT) calculation and microkinetic analysis. The results show that Rh1Ni1(111) was screened out to show optimum catalytic performance for ethanol production. This was attributed to a moderate quantity of charge transfer from Ni to Rh atoms, and a medium distance from the d -band center to the Fermi level. Further, to verify the catalytic performance of the catalysts at a Rh: Ni ratio of 1: 1, 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was prepared and its catalytic performance for ethanol preparation from syngas was investigated by comparing it with that of Rh/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/γ-Al2O3. The catalytic performance of 1Rh1Ni/γ-Al2O3 has been further confirmed to be preferred over Rh/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/γ-Al2O3, achieving a 23.0 % CO conversion rate with 31.2 % ethanol selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Ratio screening of high performance Rh-Ni catalyst for ethanol synthesis from syngas: An integration of theoretical and experimental investigation
